channel.title: Bloomberg Politics
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Labour Rebels Threaten to Kill Starmer’s UK Welfare Cuts
item.description: Labour opponents of the UK government’s £5 billion ($6.8 billion) cut to disability benefits have secured enough support to block the plan, setting up a high-stakes test of Prime Minister Keir Starmer’s leadership less than a year into office.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham

media:content.media:description: The Houses of Parliament in London. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

item.title: Israel-Iran War Truce Highlights Mystery of Missing Uranium
item.description: US President Donald Trump’s declaration of a ceasefire between Israel and Iran may curb the exchange of missile fire, but the biggest mystery of the war remains unsolved: the location of Tehran’s near-bomb-grade uranium.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Tirone

item.title: NATO Confronts Its Doomsday Scenario
item.description: The last thing the world wants to contemplate in the wake of the US-Iran military showdown is a Russian attack on NATO.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Welch

media:content.media:description: Flags of North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) member countries at the summit in The Hague, Netherlands, on Tuesday, June 24, 2025. The NATO leaders are meeting against the backdrop of heightened tensions in the Middle East. Photographer: Lina Selg/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump-Hailed Truce Falters With Israel Accusing Iran of a Breach
item.description: A ceasefire declared by US President Donald Trump between Israel and Iran is being put to the test in its early hours, after a missile fired into Israel prompted accusations of a breach.
item.dc:creator: Arsalan Shahla, Fiona MacDonald, Catherine Lucey

media:content.media:description: Israeli soldiers work in the rubble after an Iranian missile strike in Beersheba, Israel, on June 24. Photographer: Bernat Armangue/AP

item.title: UK to Spend 5% of GDP on Security by 2035 to Hit NATO Goal
item.description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer will vow to spend 5% of British economic output on security by 2035, embracing an ambitious NATO target sought by President Donald Trump without providing a path on how to get there.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Milligan

media:content.media:description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer.

item.title: Germany to Sell More Debt to Fund Merz’s Growth, Defense Plans
item.description: Germany will borrow about a fifth more than planned in the coming months to fund a surge in spending, while a deal to secure a €46 billion ($53 billion) package of tax breaks highlighted how debt needs are set to grow.
item.dc:creator: Kamil Kowalcze

item.title: Erdogan Set to Meet Trump at NATO Summit to Reset US-Turkey Ties
item.description: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan is poised to meet US President Donald Trump on the sidelines of the NATO summit in a bid to turn the page on strained relations between the two countries, people familiar with the matter said.
item.dc:creator: Selcan Hacaoglu

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump and Recep Tayyip Erdogan at the White House in Washington, DC, in 2019.

item.title: Alberta Premier Expects New Oil Pipeline Proposal Within Weeks
item.description: Alberta Premier Danielle Smith expects a private-sector firm to propose a new oil pipeline to the British Columbia coast within weeks in a bid to become one of the first entrants on the Canadian government’s list of nationally important projects.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Orland

media:content.media:description: Danielle Smith speaks in an interview at Bloomberg’s Calgary bureau.

item.title: ICC Prosecutor Blocks Duterte’s Request for Interim Release
item.description: The International Criminal Court’s deputy prosecutor has asked the pre-trial chamber to reject former Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte’s request for interim release to another country.
item.dc:creator: Cliff Harvey Venzon

media:content.media:description: TOPSHOT - Former Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte is seen on a screen in the courtroom during his first appearance before the International Criminal Court (ICC) on charge of crimes against humanity over his deadly crackdown on narcotics, in The Hague on March 14, 2025. The 79-year-old, the first ex-Asian head of state to face charges at the ICC, followed by videolink during a short hearing to inform him of the crimes he is alleged to have committed, as well as his rights as a defendant. Duterte stands accused of the crime against humanity of murder over his years-long campaign against drug users and dealers that rights groups said killed thousands. (Photo by Peter Dejong / POOL / AFP) (Photo by PETER DEJONG/POOL/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: London Population Set to Jump 600,000 Putting Strain on Housing
item.description: London’s population is expected to jump by a further 600,000 by 2032, according to official projections that suggest a ratcheting up of pressure on the capital’s constrained housing market.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees

media:content.media:description: Commuters cross London Bridge in London. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

item.title: Travel Chaos Starts to Ease as Gulf States Reopen Airspace
item.description: Air-travel disruptions started to ease in the Middle East after a ceasefire deal was reached between Israel and Iran and several Persian Gulf states reopened their airspace.
item.dc:creator: Leen Al-Rashdan, Danny Lee

media:content.media:description: An aircraft following the reopening of airspace in Doha, on June 24.

item.title: No Sign US Plans to Scale Down Forces in EU East, Lithuania Says
item.description: There are no indications “as of this morning” that the US is planning to scale down its military presence in the European Union’s eastern member states, Lithuania’s Foreign Minister Kestutis Budrys said in a Bloomberg Television interview on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Crook, Milda Seputyte

media:content.media:description: Kestutis Budrys on June 24. Photographer: Simon Wohlfahrt/Bloomberg

item.title: Asian Stocks Rise Most Since April on Mideast Truce; Kospi Jumps
item.description: Asia’s stock benchmark climbed on Tuesday, led by technology shares, as risk sentiment improved after US President Donald Trump announced a tentative ceasefire between Israel and Iran.
item.dc:creator: Winnie Hsu

media:content.media:description: A screen displays the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) and the exchange rate between the South Korean won and US dollar inside a trading room at Hana Bank in Seoul, South Korea.

item.title: NATO Cash Bonanza Risks Becoming Europe’s Lost Chance for Growth
item.description: Europe’s plans to unleash trillions of euros in new defense spending will be a huge missed opportunity unless the region can work out how to raise productivity in the process.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Migliaccio

media:content.media:description: A soldier on patrol ahead of the summit in The Hague, on June 23. Photographer: Simon Wohlfahrt/Bloomberg

item.title: Pressure to Seal Trump Trade Deals Ramps Up With Two Weeks to Go
item.description: Two weeks from President Donald Trump’s self-imposed deadline to reach deals with the US’s major trading partners, some of the most-watched talks aimed at clinching agreements to avoid higher tariffs are struggling to get over the finish line.
item.dc:creator: Katia Dmitrieva

media:content.media:description: A worker moves a shipping container at Felixstowe port in Felixstowe, UK.

item.title: French Government Under Pressure as Pension Talks Stumble
item.description: Negotiations over France’s contentious retirement reform ended in deadlock late Monday, raising pressure on the government as some opposition parties called for a no-confidence vote.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

item.title: India’s Defense Minister Heads to China After a Five-Year Gap
item.description: India’s Defense Minister Rajnath Singh will visit China — his first trip in five years — amid ongoing efforts by the world’s two most populous nations to mend ties after the 2020 border clashes.
item.dc:creator: Sudhi Ranjan Sen

media:content.media:description: Rajnath Singh, India’s defense minister, center, in New Delhi. Photographer: Hindustan Times/Hindustan Times

item.title: Israel Accuses Iran of Breaching Truce Trump Said Was in Effect
item.description: Israel has accused Iran of breaching a ceasefire announced by US President Donald Trump earlier Tuesday to end to the 12-day war.
item.dc:creator: Arsalan Shahla, Fiona MacDonald, Catherine Lucey

media:content.media:description: Smoke rises from a location allegedly IRGC's Sarallah Headquarters in north of Tehran after being targeted by Israel on June 23. Photographer: ELYAS/AFP

item.title: Germany Clears Path for €46 Billion in Tax Cuts With State Deal
item.description: Germany’s ruling coalition reached an agreement with the country’s state premiers on how to share the financial burden from a €46 billion ($53 billion) package of tax breaks intended to boost economic growth.
item.dc:creator: Michael Nienaber

media:content.media:description: The Reichstag building in Berlin. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

item.title: Thai PM Faces Legal Tests After Averting Coalition Collapse
item.description: Thailand’s anti-graft agency will probe Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra’s controversial phone call with ex-Cambodian leader Hun Sen, according to local media reports, as her rivals seek legal recourse to force her ouster.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat, Anuchit Nguyen

media:content.media:description: Paetongtarn Shinawatra

item.title: Former French PM de Villepin Forms Party Ahead of 2027 Election
item.description: Former French Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin announced late Monday he was creating a new political party ahead of the 2027 presidential election.
item.dc:creator: Julien Ponthus

media:content.media:description: Dominique de Villepin

item.title: Singapore’s Premier Vows Closer China Cooperation in Xi Meeting
item.description: Singapore’s Prime Minister Lawrence Wong pledged to deepen bilateral cooperation in a meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping, as the trade-dependent city-state confronts intensifying tensions between Beijing and Washington.
item.dc:creator: Josh Xiao

media:content.media:description: Lawrence Wong

item.title: Spain and Rutte Locked in a Showdown on Eve of NATO Summit
item.description: By refusing to agree spending increases to appease US President Donald Trump, Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez threatens to derail a NATO summit that Secretary General Mark Rutte needs to run smoothly for the sake of the military alliance’s future survival.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Palasciano

media:content.media:description: Sanchez in Albania last month.

item.title: Seoul Foreign Minister Pick to Prioritize US-North Korea Talks
item.description: South Korea’s foreign minister nominee Cho Hyun pledged to make resuming the US-North Korea dialogue a top priority, underscoring new President Lee Jae Myung’s vision of building lasting peace on the Korean Peninsula.
item.dc:creator: Hyonhee Shin

item.title: China Slams Taiwan’s Lai for Speech Mentioning Independence
item.description: China harshly condemned Taiwanese President Lai Ching-te for a speech aimed at rallying the democracy’s 23 million people to stand up to its larger neighbor — a back-and-forth that illustrates a deepening cross-strait divide.
item.dc:creator: Yian Lee

media:content.media:description: Lai Ching-te Photographer: Daniel Ceng/Anadolu/Getty Images

item.title: Japan’s Akazawa Says Still Working on Date for Next Trade Talks
item.description: Japan and the US are still working on setting the timing for the next round of cabinet-level trade talks, Japan’s point person for the negotiations said, as the deadline for a deal to avert another hike in tariffs nears.
item.dc:creator: Brian Fowler

media:content.media:description: Ryosei Akazawa

item.title: Iran-Israel War Heads Toward Pause After Trump Claims Ceasefire
item.description: Iran and Israel appeared to be nearing a pause in their 12-day war after President Donald Trump announced a surprise ceasefire in a conflict that saw key Iranian military leaders and scientists killed, US bombing of Iranian nuclear sites and a salvo of missiles launched at Qatar.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Lucey, Kate Sullivan, Fiona MacDonald, Arsalan Shahla

media:content.media:description: (Photo by ELYAS/Middle East Images/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: YouTube Exemption From Australian Teen Social Media Ban Opposed by Regulator
item.description: Australia’s online regulator called on the government to reverse its controversial exemption for YouTube from a social media ban for under-16s, an unusual intervention that echoes similar pleas from rival platforms including Facebook and TikTok.
item.dc:creator: Angus Whitley

media:content.media:description: Photo by JOSH EDELSON/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: JOSH EDELSON/AFP

item.title: Australia Must Choose Defense or Social Spending, Rabobank Says
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

item.title: Thailand Targets Cambodian Scam Centers Amid Border Dispute
item.description: Thailand announced a raft of security and trade measures to cripple transnational crime syndicates in Cambodia, as Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra seeks an upper hand in a simmering border dispute with its neighbor.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Cambodian people waiting to enter Thailand line up at the International Border Checkpoint of Poipet, Banteay Meanchey province, Cambodia, June 8, 2025. Thai Foreign Ministry spokesperson Nikorndej Balankura said on Monday that since Cambodia has shortened the permitted stay for Thai nationals to seven days, Thailand has also adjusted its policy accordingly, setting the limit of Cambodian nationals' stay in Thailand to seven days. Touch Sokhak, deputy spokesperson for Cambodia's Ministry of Interior, said on the same day that in response to Thailand's cut of the visa-stay period for Cambodian citizens, Cambodia has shortened the permitted stay for Thai citizens from 60 days to seven days. (Photo by Meanchey/Xinhua via Getty Images)
